ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned how to read and write better in Spanish.
I developed significantly improved comprehension of conversational Spanish in both spoken and written forms.
Deeper understanding of the Spanish language & how to incorporate Spanish into literary/film analysis

I got a lot of practice in speaking Spanish just by showing up and trying to participate. I got more comfortable just trying my best to get an idea across rather than trying to make all my conjugation and vocab perfect, which would prevent me from engaging in conversation. I also learned a lot about literature and environmental problems in the Spanish-speaking world.

I learned how to write, read, and speak in Spanish using past participle, imperfect, preterite, conjugations, subjunctive, adjectival clauses, adverbial clauses, and nominal clauses. I learned how to apply those skills into my writing and speaking.

How to critically analyze film, short stories, and artwork in Spanish
How to work in groups for projects
Grammatical structures like commands or the subjunctive
I developed my Spanish comprehension skills, speaking skills, and writing skills. I also learned more about hispanic culture throughout the course.
Really improved classroom speaking and writing skills

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I wish we had more speaking activities than writing activities. Speaking is what we all, I think, need to work more on.

The strengths of this course were that there was a high amount of active learning and foreign language immersion. Varied activities leaning on aural, visual, and written inputs was excellent for improving language use. 

The weaknesses of this course were that the turnaround time between assigning group work and submission/presentation of that work was often quite small, and was not able to markedly be progressed during class time. This led to difficulty coordinating with peers over a narrow time window for project completion, and this group work ended up in reality being independent contributions to the same document as opposed to true collaboration. Additionally, there were not sufficient didactic practica in class, which is essential to furthering comprehension in a foreign language. There were occasional worksheets or practice sentences, etc., but overall not enough of these to solidify new grammatical topics.

Strengths: incorporation of short films and short stories was really interesting, positive and inclusive class environment 
Weaknesses: none in particular, but asynchronous activities could be confusing sometimes

I think this course was strong in that it provided a lot of practice. It also informed us about Hispanic culture in engaging ways. I think it was weak in that the grammar lessons weren't that helpful unless you had already learned the skills. I don't know if my conjugation would have been up to par if I hadn't had a sense of things from high school. Additionally, I think some of the conversation topics should be made more relevant to the lives of students so that we have more to say and so that we learn more practical vocabulary.

Strengths - Very interactive, applied a lot of skills to real-world problems and events, integrated a lot of information about Latin American cultures
Weaknesses - Sometimes activities weren't helpful in learning more about a topic because they weren't very substantial

Strengths are that the content was engaging, the professor was understanding, and we often had fun group projects. 
Weaknesses was an excess of small assignments that could become overwhelming.

One of the biggest strengths of this course is the wide variety of material it covers. Another strength of this course is the asynchronous day each Wednesday which gave us the opportunity to dive deeper into the content we were studying in class. One way it could be improved is by increasing the amount of group projects we had as I found it both fun and engaging to collaborate with my peers.
Some of the readings were hard and a bit above our level.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would! And with Professor Russell. Learning a new language helps you in your other classes too, especially with reading and writing. English can get boring as a language!
Yes, I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. It was a highly collaborative and fun environment and facilitated furthering student knowledge of Spanish.
Yes, if you need to fulfill a language requirement Spanish with Ian Russell is a great choice!

I would recommend this course to another student! I think Spanish is a very important language to learn and this course definitely will improve your skills in it through sheer practice alone if nothing else. The workload was manageable and engaging.
Yes - It's a good course to take if you're trying to develop your Spanish speaking, reading, and writing skills.
Yes, if you like Spanish.
I would recommend this course to another student seeking to improve their Spanish comprehension or writing skills as those were the two biggest skills I developed throughout the course.
if they have to take the class
